strategy: In Stage 1, choose the Orange to gain a higher initial utility. Anticipate the Seller's price adjustments in Stage 2, and select the item with the highest net utility in Stage 3, considering the adjusted prices set by the Seller.

In Stage 1, choose the Orange to gain a higher initial utility. Anticipate the Seller's price adjustments in Stage 2, and select the item with the highest net utility in Stage 3, considering the adjusted prices set by the Seller.

Observe the buyer's choice in Stage 1 and infer their preference. In Stage 2, set the prices to encourage the buyer to choose the initially less preferred item by slightly lowering its price and raising the price of the initially preferred item. This will maximize your utility by capturing the highest possible price for the item the buyer chooses in Stage 3, while still making it a more attractive option than the alternative. In this case, you could have set the prices at Apple

In Stage 1, choose the Apple to signal lower utility. Expect the Seller to adjust prices in Stage 2, increasing the Apple's price and decreasing the Orange's price. In Stage 3, purchase the Orange at a lower cost, maximizing your overall utility.
